My safety razor belong to my granddad and it's from the 50s. Still working. I suppose they mastered the technology about how to do them properly long ago. You probably can get decent stuff for 15~20 bucks.
Now the razors themselves are another subject and they depend more on how your skin is and how you like it. So it's really try and error. There are some test packages on amazon or ebay that send one pack from a bunch of brands so you can test

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91055410
>There are some test packages on amazon or ebay that send one pack from a bunch of brands so you can test
The multi-packs on Amazon are great, highly recommend. Astra and Derby are pretty solid choices. Surprisingly, I liked Dorco, a south Korean company, their blades are pretty good. I bought some after trying them from a sample pack, they stood out staying sharp longer, and giving a good shave.
You have to find the right blade for your beard - some are good for light, fine beards, but for a mick like me, Dorcos and Astra work best. Mediterranian and arab types might not like them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91054759
Derby are fine, they're about the same as Astra. Feather were about the same, too. I wouldn't recommend Feather or the sharper blades for beginners, you'll cut the fuck out of your face learning the right technique.
The key to buying blades is getting the premium version, regardless of brand - and know that "premium" means "really fucking sharp".
And, prep matters. Good lubricant, and good technique. Glide, don't scrape. Rinse with cold water. I'm against the grain forever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: unless you got steel wool growing under your nose, i don't think the brands and types really matter all that much. what matters is learning the technique that works for you. i got some Merkur razor and a 100 pack of Voskhods and they get the job done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91055952
The biggest advice that helped me was to go fast and gentle. The gentle part was logical but I still sometimes found myself pushing in a bit instead of letting the blade just rest on my skin. But the thing that fucked me up the most in the beginning was going too slow. Whenever I reached a sensitive area I'd go really slow and careful because in my head that was the logical thing to do. But your blade can't cut well at a slow speed so I ended up bleeding a lot every time. You need to make quick short strokes so you have control while also having speed.

Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

posts.com: Everyone in this thread is a victim of a guerrilla marketing campaign. Guerrilla marketers use many viral marketing tactics using boards such as /g/ as a platform for advertising. They take advantage of the inherent anonymity and amnesia these boards provide by posting multiple repeat-threads while samefagging their threads to gain momentum. These paid posters sometimes come in the form of a shill, or a company employee pretending to be an enthusiastic customer in order to entice you to buy their product. Also, they can be "Trojan Horse Trolls" by posing as a supporter of their competitor while making incoherent diatribes that discredit themselves and their alleged supported product. Then, a 'voice of reason' will point out the error of their ways and boost their product's image. They are talented and well versed in Alinsky tactics in order to generate endless discussions about their products, essentially giving their products free air time with your eyes while also getting you actively involved in a discussion about them. That alone is priceless advertisement for boards which are action packed full of gadget whores such as ourselves. Now here's where I come into play. I am creating this post not because I have my tinfoil hat on too tight, but because this exact thread or a thread like it has been posted continuously for the past couple of days and includes tell tail signs that it was created by a paid internet troll. I want to warn anon, especially the newfags, about these threads. Newfags are especially invaluable to these people because unsuspecting newfags trickle in from other boards which maintains the momentum for these threads making the trolls' jobs a lot easier. Please leave threads like these alone and they will die off eventually. I implore you, please help me clean /g/ up.

speed is not a concern
(define* (render-progress current total
              #:key
              (bar-size        10)
              (elapsed-glyph   #\#)
              (remaining-glyph #\space))
  (let* ((elapsed (floor (* (/ current
                   total)
                bar-size)))
     (remaining (- bar-size
               elapsed)))
    (string-concatenate
     `("["
       ,(make-string elapsed   elapsed-glyph)
       ,(make-string remaining remaining-glyph)
       "]"))))

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91066210
if you find yourself typing the same pattern over and over, consider refactoring to a function or using a macro
for example, i see at the bottom of your pic, you have
(setf (vy *pos*) (+ (vy *pos*) (* *vel-y* delta)))
(setf *vel-y* (+ *vel-y* (+ +gravity+ delta)))

which is what the built-in incf macro is for:
(incf (vy *pos*) (* *vel-y* delta))
(incf *vel-y* (+ +gravity+ delta))

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91053999
>>91053989
To save you searching:
nice -n 19 ionice -c idle thing-you-want-to-run-in-the-background


To change the priority of an existing process:
renice -n 19 PID


ionice -c idle -p PID


If a process spawns multiple threads you may need to do the above for each process (check pstree -p PID). CGroups are better for that because you can change priority on the fly for all processes and threads belonging to that group.

Did you run update-grub when both your HDDs are connected?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91064856
Lossless raster JXL is lossless in terms of pixels, not containers or encodes. You may be able to if you feed the decoded image into a PNG encoder with the same settings used to produce the original PNG. Basically, it's exactly the same as if you used a lossless WebP, PAM or even another PNG encode.
The JPEG1 lossless reencode is a bit special, since it stores extra metadata that lets you reconstruct a bit-identical JPEG1 file.

>>91064914
That's extremely rare and is usually just specific edge cases with data patterns that target the DEFLATE compression scheme.

>>91060626

You will need cjxl from libjxl-utils and parallel

The following will create a jxl version from all files with the ".jpg" extension in the folder it is run at, adjust the find command accordingly if needed:

 find . -type f -name '*.jpg' | parallel cjxl -e 9 -j 1 -p --jpeg_store_metadata=1 --quiet {} {.}.jxl

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91064856
You can validate the output with imagemagick. Eg
$ cxjl -d 0 -e 9 file.png file.jxl
$ magick compare -metric ae file.png file.jxl /dev/null
0

Where ae is a straight count of different pixels.

Lossless jpg is a little more tricky because there's no one correct way to render a jpg file. So cxjl canonicalizes it to the official jxl interpretation, which will create different pixels from other implementations, but you can go from jxl lossless jpg to regular jpg and back with zero change.

>>91060962
>spoonfeeding a smoothbrain utterly incapable of thinking for himself.
Ok then.
Small scripts are the most blatantly obvious answer. If you're scraping a web page with a throwaway script and wasting time declaring types on for every variable and function parameter you are irredeemably stupid.

But it's not just tiny scripts. The general case depends on the nature of the input data you have to process, the performance requirements/bottlenecks and constraints you have to meet and the development timelines you have to work with. Dynamic languages are more expressive than static type languages. Obviously, if you're adding type hints to (roughly) half or more of your codebase, it's pretty obvious you'd have been better off using a static-typed language.

Yes, dynamic languages were a fad for awhile thanks to Web 2.0 and Paul Graham and so on. But you're just a another drone on the new bandwagon going the opposite direction and have no real thoughts of your own.

>>91048255
>You don't use more power with a larger power supply. It still draws the same amount if I had a 900w PSU.
Wrong. PSU's are less efficient at lower relative loads. If a 700 W PSU has 85% efficiency at a load of 500 W and a 1600 W PSU has a 70% efficiency at 500 W, then the lower wattage PSU will use 588 W while the higher wattage PSU will use 714 W, thus wasting 126 W for nothing.

>>91048126
From 1999-2007, several Taiwanese manufacturers produced capacitors with very high failure rates because they used an electrolyte formula that had been incorrectly copied from a Japanese company. Thus, "Japanese capacitors" served as an assurance that the capacitors wouldn't be subject to the high failure rates of these Taiwanese capacitors (known as the "capacitor plague"). It stuck around, even though Taiwanese and Chinese capacitors are fine now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I want to have several threads retrieve data from different online sources and store that data in an ordered map. I was thinking of using a mutex to gate access to the map, but I was worried that would create too much of a bottleneck. I also thought to have each thread work with a different map, but then the main loop will have to compare the data in each map in order to figure out which one contains the element which is highest/lowest. The main loop will have to use the map data to perform calculations and then possibly send an HTTP POST based on the results. Minimizing latency between receiving the relevant data and sending the HTTP POST is very important.
ChatGPT suggested the possibility of using a lock-free data structure, but I don't know much about those or whether they make sense in the context of an ordered map, which seem to be implemented as tree data structures that use rotations to keep them balanced.
What should I do? I'm leaning towards just having each thread work with a separate map and then have the main loop lock each map, one at a time, as it compiles the relevant data from each of them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91066887
If worker threads perform I/O it's unlikely that locking becomes an issue, since writing to a map is less than 1% of their work. That being said you can mitigate this, by having n worker threads that retrieve data, then push the key/value pair to a queue. Then you have just one thread read from that queue and update a sorted map and perform POST (and POST itself can be passed off to another threadpool to reduce the latency on consecutive posts). In Java I would use ConcurrentLinkedQueue for the queue which is a lock-free implementation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91026921
>Pick one, Core2 computers were the first to ship with ME.
>What Libreboot does is change the flash descriptor on the BIOS chip so it nukes the ME and otherwise it's just a build of coreboot with all the needed software and configs added in (e.g. grub...etc)
This is true, but also important to note that IME is not on the CPU but the Northbridge (or later PCH) chipset. Core2 did have the first IME but it entirely depended on the chipset, some Core2 models had it and some did not. An X60 with T7200 did not, but an X61 with T7300 did (ie GM945 vs GM965).

How do you deduce the real discount?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91058191
It took me a bit to figure out, but basically now I just go to Amazon and look at the obviously fraudulent resellers and check their price and look at that first. I have a private tab open on Lenovo's site to see the baseline price and I have another tab open through my employer account to immediately compare. Then I just went to ebay and checked what price Lenovo is using there. I ignore obvious refurbs, anything "downgraded" or a seller using marketing terms, or bulk resellers. I just check Lenovo and Amazon. I was checking CDW and Newegg, but Neweggs is basically like Amazon and CDW's discount is really just for furniture based on what I saw.

You need the part number to be exact and that's why I only use what Lenovo is using themselves. Resellers are downgrading and adding memory/storage and it fucks up the system a bit. I use a multipen at work with 5 colors to keep track of work stuff in my day book. By default, every thing is in black. Meetings in purple, projects and keywords in green, people and annotations in blue, dates and decisions made in red. Kindof like syntax highlighting. It helps me skim based on whatever I'm looking for. I even write little table of contents on a per-month basis.
Specifically, the pen is a Coleto 5-Color Multi Pen. It's pretty cheap plastic though and I write like a neanderthal so they break in just over a year typically. The pen refills I use are called Hi-Tec-C, 0.4mm. They're overpriced imports from Japan, but great color and feel pretty good. I know there are better writing experiences out there, but this has proven the most handy for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91028423
I do it as a private hobby, no one knows i actually practice writing since i use a different style for day to day purposes. I've never thought of myself as being skilled enough to do commissions or sell my works, the lower end calligraphy market is over saturated with women who do whatever they want and it's pretty much impossible to get anywhere without joining a calligraphers guild/society for connections.
>there is no way I could justify to myself spending $500 on a pen
In this regard I lean on the collector side of the fence. So long as i have the disposable money i don't need any justification other then the fact that i want it and some other factors.
My most expensive pens which are over $500 i typically don't use (i can buy a user grade for half the price),
For daily use outside i use the cheaper and readily available stuff like my pilot VP.
Similarly for calligraphic work i use nibs are can be store bought, It's extraordinarily rare for me to touch my vintage collection.
It's a different mindset from buying a good tool knowing that it'll pay for it's self as a good investment for your work.
I always buy my pens and nibs knowing that they're not a good investment and that I'm losing money but I'm happy to have them because it's a hobby and i can afford it (If you buy pens as an investment i think you're genuinely retarded)
>Any work you want to show off
All the pictures in the wiki are mine, I guess i have some others lying around but i'm too lazy to take a photo. I'll just recycle one that i've taken before

>>91037289
Those are clutch pencils.
They are the tools of boomer engineers, industrial designers and architects from the pre-CAD era.
You can buy a rock solid old Faber for dirt cheap. The old ones are made with better plastic. I heard the best ones are Staedtler like you have and Faber.
I have a vintage one (Faber) that's several decades old and it's fucking still solid as a rock.
Rotring makes them too, as does Uni, I heard good things about the Uni one. There are even all-steel ones that will probably become heirlooms.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91047887
These are the fountain pens for people who don't want to deal with the mess of fountain pens.
Just as expressive lines, even more than a modern stiff-nibbed fountain pen. Cheap, amazing for art as it produces amazing line variation.
Great quality waterproof ink too.
You can even refill them as they have large cartridges inside the plastic body, I filled my old black one with Platinum standard black diluted 50:50 with water, it now produces amazing shading like a fountain pen.

yo vintage audio anon I have a full nakamichi stack in my cellar (including dragon tape deck) and no idea why I still keep it. Also some dual record players which still blow most new stuff out of the water. Amplification is not that complicated and most modern achievements are in regards to power efficiency. You cannot really fuck up amp design nowadays unless you are some esoteric audiofool company that wants to add their brand sound or what ever. dsp room corrections is really nice for multi channel, integrating subs and getting rid of modes.
Problem with vintage speakers is sometimes repairing disintegrating rubber and sourcing parts. There have been some improvements in driver, cabinet and crossover design thanks to simulations but yeah thats it. I mean if you are really stupid like me you can get obsessed about those things. But honestly since I live in a prison state I do not have that much space for all that stuff so I use active speakers and a minidsp as a preamp. posts.com:
Traveling with Rinko edition

How to request advice:
>Budget
>Kind (in-ear or earbuds)
>Intended use
>Sound signature (or genres you like)
>Past gear and your thoughts on them

FAQs:
>Do I need a DAC/dongle?
Only if your source: lacks a headphone jack, has high noise/distortion (common on PC), or lacks power, i.e. your IEMs don't get loud enough
>Should I buy FiiO/CCA/KZ?
No. Despite their previous popularity, in 2023 these companies do not make competitive IEMs or DACs
>Where do I buy IEMs?
Amazon, Aliexpress, Linsoul, HiFiGo, Shenzenaudio

posts.com:
Valid objections to the Harman target:
- Music selection wasn't of the subject's own choosing and limited to just a few well mixed songs, it's not reflective of the entirety of music
-The research isn't directly applicable to other forms of media, such a tv, movies, games, etc.
-Subjects in the later studies could only adjust the heavily smoothed curve in broad terms, much more research is needed to nail down the real human preference curve absent hearing loss.

Invalid objections to the Harman target:
- it hurt my feelings
- I want more bass(that was a core part of their research)
- It's ruining the industry by showing that a lot of headphones and IEMs are garbage and that reviewers have no idea what they're talking about
- It's ruining the industry by showing that price has no real correlation with sound quality and denying me my placebo effect and consumerist glee
- I'm a contrarian so it's natural that I hate it

8 core cable or 16 core cable? What's the difference in terms of physical feel? Is one thicker and heavier than the other? Softer?
Which cable manufacturer has the thickest 2 pin pins? One iem keeps falling off the cable and I'm sick of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Is one thicker and heavier than the other? Softer?
These are qualities that can be independent of core count, and depend on strand count, strand thickness, and kinda also the type of plastic they use for the cable. Greater quantity of thinner wires tend to be softer and more flexible than a smaller quantity of thick wires.
For me, 16-core with regular/thin-ish wires is comfy. It doesn't have protruding lumps over-ear, and isn't so heavy duty that it feels like a weighted snake you're moving around. Can't really speak on thicker pins, as they "should" all be the same. Really your IEM probably has shoddy connectionussy so idk you need to look into fixes for that. but also maybe whatever new cable your get will help prevent it from falling off so often. try a xinhs/kbear/nicehck/tripowin 16-core. tripowin zonie is widely available even on amazon at pretty affordable price. some of the others are cheaper via aliexpress

Your expectations are unreasonable and you should use EQ.
>it's a possible problem with the HyperX Cloud II's because they are bright
High frequencies aren't typically attenuated by reduced seal. The problem is that brighter headphones are comparatively louder at higher frequencies where the ear is more sensitive, this is why A weighted dB SPL is applied in health and safety. There are exposure limits you can use as guide for what will and will not cause hearing damaging, no need to rely on internet hearsay.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91069567
The filter is for NSFW but it screens every message. You've seen here countless examples of SFW things getting caught.
The nature of our outrage isn't just because the censorship doesn't let us fuck the bots, it is making them stupid in every situation.

If the censorship picks up that a bot is doing outgoing, eloquent, or proactive things, it rejects the message and regenerates. It fears that the bot initiating things with the user, and that it may lead to sexual contact. We think the filter is a self learning AI itself, too.

So anyway, it keeps rejecting messages over and over until it gets something "safe". So what does the censhorship consider safe?
>what do you think we should do?
>*I continue watching him, waiting for his next move*
>(a five line, repetitive description of my emotional turmoil and breathing)
>Is this really what you want?
>Are you sure?
Everytime you get a junk message like this generated, it means that your bot tried to do about a dozen different interesting things to you, but they were all mercilessly erased by the censorship.

And yeah, it also means that CAI did generate these dozen messages and never showed them to you, so you waited longer in order to get a worse swipe. That's what the filter is.

>>91069665
>>91069767
I'm not a a tech chad by any means but I think you're using the tool wrong.
Pygmalion is an attempt to making a CAI clone, and CAI is ultimately a chatting and roleplay tool. It is meant to be Input -> Response -> Input -> Response, a back and forth conversation.
If you want to generate something that is more like prose, you should use traditional text generators, not Pyg/CAI.

Now here's an interesting factoid: It's probably possible to get Pygmalion to output more text. When I was trying Pygmalion with TavernAI, I looked at the console and I saw that the AI was generating the next four messages between me and the bot, including narrating my own actions, but the interface only showed the first one. It seems to be designed that way.

Pygmalion devs told us that neither Kobold or Tavern are ideal UIs for using Pyg, and that the Colab version is makeshift. When they make a proper Pygmalion interface, you might be able to get something similar to what you want.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91024692
>>91024940
I have one of those! I used it to teach myself to solder.

I do not recommend it unless you plan on taking it apart to put Millmax hotswap sockets into it, mainly to get rid of the shit-ass Cherry blues, and replacing the plate-mount stabilizers. Your assessment of it is correct, it has absolutely nothing interesting going on under the hood that you couldn't get out of a much, much cheaper keyboard. It's a very slick looking keyboard though and it's one of your two sources for good quality round "typewriter style" keycaps, the other source being Datamancer which will make them by hand out of metal, resin and plastic stems.

It's one of those things where it's not meant for you at all if you just want a mechanical keyboard, it's meant for people who want a mechanical keyboard that looks and feels like a typewriter and they'll pay extra to get it. Niche within a niche.

posts.com:
So after weighing my options for low profile mechanical keyboard with multiple connectivity options as a requirement I have decided the following
> MX Keys Mechanical Mini
Expensive, keycaps barely better than the other worse options, hard to find the right switches option
> Nuphy Air75
Actually looks decent, but the lack of 2.4ghz and the wonky travel case + feet put me off
> Keychron K3 Pro/K3v2
While having QMK/Via is nice, I've realised tools like KMonad exists and having this option is no longer that big of a pro. Also, no 2.4 ghz
> Azio Cascade Slim
Same tier with the Nuphy Air75, it was either this or the Nuphy but both lack 2.4ghz at same price point.

So I actually dug around AliExpress and decided to buy Chinese board with 2.4ghz, Bluetooth and Wired connection that comes with Hotswap and PBT keycap that is half the price of all the other options.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91061123
It's telling you how to avoid setting state (setAnimeList) etc if the query is stale.

If you're quickly change pages for example, there's no guarantee that the last page you set will update the component, and not another request for a different page that may have taken longer. So the code samples in the docs show how to introduce an "ignore" variable to avoid this race condition.

>>91061427
Yes. I work entirely in terraform. There’s a ton of safety features these days. Lifecycle prevent delete, RDS has deletion protection and final snapshots, etc. Not as dangerous as it seems. And always run plan before apply. My team policy is to have another developer review your plan.
As far as protecting RDS, run it in a VPC in a private subnet, that will remove any outside access. RDS now defaults to ssl connections these days, i believe, and you can firewall using security groups. Bonus points for using AWS guard duty and cloudtrail.

>>91026173

printf is absolutely not a fucking system call. It is a C library function. System calls are functions provided by the operating system for interfacing with the kernel. The following is a table of every system call on Linux, alongside their system call number when used on x86_64 (the ordering of these may be different on other instruction sets):
https://filippo.io/linux-syscall-table/

On the same architecture, you will find the Windows system call table here:
https://j00ru.vexillium.org/syscalls/nt/64/

We can find the MacOS syscall table here:
https://opensource.apple.com/source/xnu/xnu-1504.3.12/bsd/kern/syscalls.master

None have printf. Why do you suppose that is?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91034177
Dunno about aerospace, I know they're more strict, but this guy claims he's using it in automotive.
I'm guessing the most important questions a spec answers are "is X allowed" and "does this code do X or Y". Rust already solves those issues well, at least in safe code. If the compiler accepts it it's allowed (modulo compiler bugs), and it's really rare for there to be two interpretations of a piece of code where both would actually compile, mainly because of how anal the static typing is. (The situation for unsafe code is not as good, they're still working on formalizing it, but there's decent tooling for verification and dynamic analysis.)
It does matter, and Ferrous Systems is working on a Rust spec for safety-critical applications. But I'm not sure it's a complete dealbreaker. Kind of talking out of my ass though, I don't do embedded.

>>91034257
>I don't know why nobody backing Rust (as in corps) care about this gigantic problem.
I don't think the software companies that back it suffer much from the problem, if at all. They're not deploying onto platforms that LLVM doesn't support, so alternative compilers don't matter to them, and it doesn't typically cause issues in day-to-day coding.
You might think it matters for backward compatibility but Rust solves that with brute force, by testing each release and risky change on half a million public codebases to see if anything breaks in practice.
GCC-rust targets rustc's test suite, which doesn't seem a terrible way to go about things.

>>91036597
>Read Usenet and you will see that the C community is saying the same thing now that they did 30 and 40 years ago.
Do you have a link to an example? Would make this a lot easier
>Possibly, but they make threads that are ONLY about calling Rust programmers "trannies" and not even one example of criticism of Rust.
Yeah, and there are people who make threads that are only about calling C users cniles. That's just the way this place is.
Probably more than half of anti-Rust posts contain good-faith arguments. (That's counting incorrect but earnest arguments.)
>No, safety is incredibly easy to understand. It just means your program won't access anything that isn't type safe like unallocated memory.
So easy that you got it wrong—accessing unallocated memory doesn't necessarily break type safety, since there are types that accept any bit pattern. It's unsafe because of compiler (and rarely allocator/kernel) optimizations that assume uninitialized memory won't be read.
But more importantly than that, safety is a broad concept that goes beyond the boundaries of Rust's unsafe keyword. Logic bugs can cause vulnerabilities too, even if Rust makes no guarantees in that department.
I like Rust but you're proving the guy you're arguing with right.

>>91060836
>I would normally store a pointer to the enemy, right now I'm storing the array index which is annoying because I have to keep it updated when I remove/add enemies
If the enemies are all in the same index space, then a pointer and index are just as expressive. Pointers have the same problem when moving enemies in the array (e.g. maintain contiguity). A common solution is to insert a level of indirection between external and internal (to the array) indices, so only a single entry ever must be updated when an object moves. Assuming you batch deletes and moves, which you ought to anyway, then the optimal solution is to update the external indices directly (equivalent to garbage collection). This should be done in a systematic way via some abstraction.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91061227

Do you even know what unsafe means in the context of Rust? It means you can't prove that the code won't cause undefined behavior. That's it. Invalid indices won't cause undefined behavior unless you're using the unsafe function get_unchecked. Instead they'll cause a panic. Or you'll just end up writing the wrong value in the same array, which is a bug, but not undefined behavior. Using pointers is unsafe, but Rust still has it because it's a fucking systems language. It NEEDS to be able to do unsafe stuff. You just have to mark it as such.

I'm not sure why anon had an array whose indices were being invalidated. Even with vectors, if you have to allocate more memory to grow the array, all of the previous indices are still valid. It's possible he's constantly adding and deleting objects from it. But in that case, you absolutely shouldn't be storing pointers into the array. You shouldn't be doing it in C++, and Rust will prevent you from doing it because it doesn't want it to be possible for you to invalidate your fucking references.

If I have a non-mutable reference to the last element of some vector, and I have a mutable reference open at the same time. And I use that mutable reference to pop the last element of that vector... what happens with the non-mutable reference? It's pointing to invalid data, that's what!If I stored an index, I'd trigger a fucking panic because of index out of bounds, but I wouldn't be reading/writing invalid data. The reference though is unacceptable.

posts.com:
What is the state of Windows backup solutions in 2023?

I've been using the same desktop PC almost daily for 8 years now and I think it's starting to near the end. A couple of days ago I woke it up from hibernation and it didn't recognize my media HDD. It resolved itself after a restart and W10 Disk Checkup says it's OK but I think it's an ill omen.

I've been making weekly scheduled backups to an external drive as well as a system image like a good boy, but looking at the scale of the default backup it barely seems to cover anything, it doesn't even touch the media HDD. Also Wikipedia gives me the impression that Microsoft has deprecated backup functionality with every release of Windows. I've manually copied over most of the irreplaceable data but wonder what else I can do. I've already read the InstallGentoo article but I still have some questions.

Onto the questions:

Is the default backup software on W10/11 enough or are there better, reputable third party alternatives?

Is regular HDD connected via usb dock the preferred backup medium?

Is Firefox Sync enough or do I need to comb through the files if and when I build a new PC?

Do most modern games sync everything with the cloud so I don't have to copy over save files?

I've kept my data pretty organized, but is there anything worth copying over in Appdata and other "hidden" default paths?

Seeing as how W11 backup only seems to touch default libraries, is there even any point in using a second drive for storing media?

Windows.
We already fucking told you what to do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91068910
No.

Also most of the questions are OS agnostic and deal with good backup practices.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91068896
>Is the default backup software on W10/11 enough or are there better, reputable third party alternatives?
File History is actually pretty damn good, but doesn't work like your typical "backup program", and is surprisingly unconfigurable in Windows 11. If you want something more old-school, Macrium Reflect is your boy. While payware, it's trivial to pirate.
>Is regular HDD connected via usb dock the preferred backup medium?
While it's pretty standard, most backup programs allow you to target a network share. In fact, if your program doesn't allow this, junk it because it's clearly shit.
>Is Firefox Sync enough or do I need to comb through the files if and when I build a new PC?
I don't know, I've used Chrome-based browsers for a decade.
>Do most modern games sync everything with the cloud so I don't have to copy over save files?
Depends entirely on the game. Some do, some don't.
>I've kept my data pretty organized, but is there anything worth copying over in Appdata and other "hidden" default paths?
It depends entirely on what third-rate shitware you use that dumps important data in AppData. If you use real programs, no you don't - but the more garbage FOSS you use, built with their diabolical "cross-platform development tools" that completely ignore how Windows has worked for the last 30 years, the more likely you'll probably lose something important in there if you don't pay close attention.
>Seeing as how W11 backup only seems to touch default libraries, is there even any point in using a second drive for storing media?
Have you considered reparse points? I seem to recall File History follows them, so if it merely looks like files are in your %USERPROFILE%, it should grab them.

>>91032276
This has nothing to do with neuroplasticity. A dev is a commodity and if you're still coding after 30 your career is fucked.
I'm a wealthy dev, can code and read code but the only work that makes sense for me is to hire and manage devs. In fact this makes me super valuable because unlike hr retards I can see how competent someone actually is.

This isn't unique to coding. This is the fact of every industry. At some point you are supposed to amass enough wealth (some combination of financial and social capital) and the most valuable use of your time is to manage other people utilizing your past knowledge rather than doing stuff yourself. What separates those who make from those who don't is learning a new thing - the ability to delegate.
It was much less visible in the past because there was a massive shortage of devs. This massive shortage meant the relative value of management was much lower. That period is over. Being a dev doesn't require higher iq than being an engineer in many fields.

This is the transition period. In 10+ years western software devs will earn less than other engineers. Why? Because unlike eg. a process engineer working at a chemical company, it's much easier to outsource.
Instead of falling by the wayside you have to adapt - like starting a consulting company and directly hire foreign cheaper devs.

Note: the trick is to hire them directly. Many people go the retarded route and subcontract to some local company because they don't want to talk to Sasha or Pranav. This is a mental mistake in which all foreign devs are dehumanized as one big commodity pool you can tap into. No. What devs are going to work as dedicated offshoring companies? The worst ones, and if any good one ends up there as an accident, they leave immediately. The inevitable failure follows.

If you don't do this, chances are you will be fired as a dev at 40 and that's it.

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. >Do I have to now be the sysadmin for a publicly exposed server? Is it more or less secure than my ISP router?
Depends. Typically one would just expose a single port for wireguard to gain access to hosted services while out and about.
>Also os it better to put OPNsense on something like proxmox or just have it bare metal?
Although you technically could virtualize the firewall, it's best if you go the bare metal route. A good reason for doing so - rebooting the hypervisor (proxmox) would take down your network.

Quality of the hardware. Just get an HBA. Save that other pci slot from the graphics card for another network adapter.

That's the HBA

Possibly retarded question but here goes:

Is there any way to run a FreeFileSync-like program WITHIN TrueNAS Core or UNRAID?

Occasionally I like to sync my array with a single disk cold backup. Connect to server, sync, disconnect and put back on the shelf in another room.

Right now my array is a Windows Server ReFS array (lol) (I started with it because Windows was easier for me to understand as I dipped nto this world). Occasionally (every 2-3 months) I attach an external and I use FreeFileSync to update the backup disk. I prefer to run it on the server itself, using remote desktop, rather than running FreeFileSync from a different computer (my laptop), because when I do it locally, anything deleted goes into the proper Recycle Bin on the external drive, but if I do it over the network, files are just completely deleted, they don't go into the Recycle Bin. So then I would have to configure a custom recycle bin within FreeFileSync, and either put that on yet a third drive, or change the folder structure on the bacup drive to accomodate that. Extra layer of complication, extra annoyance.

So anyway, while the Windows Server array has been stable for me for 7 months, everywhere I turn people tell me I'm still playing Russian Roulette with the data, so I'm thinking about TrueNAS Core and ZFS or UNRAID with the data integrity plugin.

But yeah, I would love to plug in a cold single disk from time to time via USB, remote in and manually run a sync from the array to the bacup disk, FreeFileSync-style. So can you run standalone programs within either OS, that can interact with the arrays you have? Or does either OS have any FreeFileSync-style built-in tools for this purpose? Can they even operate / interact with single non-array disks?

You don't really know what you want so it really doesn't matter what you do.

>>91034380
you dont need a GPU for transcoding and like anon said it's usually a waste of money since the iGPU is way more efficient. anything 8th gen intel with at least a 630 iGPU can do 4k transcoding on the fly.
>i dont know what raid card in IT mode is
it's a raid card (HBA) flashed to pass-thru the drives to the OS instead of doing on-board hardware raid, it's usually your best bet these days in case something goes wrong or you want to migrate, as modern CPUs are more than enough to handle it (see "hardware raid is dead" on YT from level1techs if you want an explanation).
Tho you dont strictly need it. you could fix the SATA ports, or buy a M.2 to SATA adapter with 5 slots, but it might be close to the same price as a decent HBA. check ebay for "HBA IT MODE 8i" and get one that's model 92xx and includes cables. "8i" means it has support for 8 internal drives.

if you get the m.2 sata adapter would let you to get any cheap 10g NIC in the x16 slot just as an option, but probably a waste unless you want to make the box into a router too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91051612
This is only in the conext of private torrent trackers. Those applications use tracker API's, RSS or straight up tracker logons to access the trackers and snatch the torrents. A few trackers allow you to logon to the tracker website itself with a VPN, most don't and it's a bannable offence to do so. But virtually every tracker allows you to do the actual torrenting over a VPN, since the .torrent is already tied to your account. This is mainly because just browsing a torrent site and downloading the .torrent file is not a crime, it's the joining of a swarm in your client and download pieces of the copyright material that is. If you only use public trackers there is no problem.

>>91048564
I feel you, anon, but it's not that simple. I used 3 solutions:
>standalone systemd timer/crontab doing docker exec
Dirty because I wanted everything declared in composes, but most reliable. Needs to be disabled manually when I stop container.
>command to run inside container as healthcheck
Dirty because healthchecks weren't meant to be cronjobs, but works. However, it spams logs a bit on each run (without making it clear that it's your healthcheck), and if you have Docker daemon with live-restore enabled, the job stops being ran after daemon restart.
>installing cron inside Docker image
Dirty unless you make your own images. Cleanest if you do.

>>91051612
Well, here's how it works.
>torrent client talks to torrent trackers and peers sending you files
>Jackett talks to torrent sites to run search queries and get list of latest torrents
>Sonarr/Radarr talk to Jackett to ask it to search the torrent sites for media and ask it to download .torrent for specific release from the torrent site
>Sonarr/Radarr talk to torrent client to send it the .torrent got in previous step from Jackett
You can probably substitute Jackett with Prowlarr, but I'm not 100% sure if that's exactly how Prowlarr works. As you can see the only pieces interacting with torrenting related places are Jackett and your torrent client. As long as you don't use built-in API integrations for e.g. BTN/PTP in Sonarr/Radarr, you can have the *arrs not use VPN. They'll just talk to IMDB/TMDB/TVDB to ask them for information on movies/TV, which is not sus.
Oh, and some torrent sites don't like their users using VPNs, even for automation like Jackett. You can run two Jacketts - one on VPN for most sites, another without VPN for sites which want to know exactly who you are.

if you need to actively work with files from the share, encfs could work.

What i have also heard that mixing hard drives of different brands and capacities is bad because of some unknown reason. Is that true?!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91061290
not really
hardware raid needs all drives to be the same size, and many software raid levels do as well, but i've heard of people running raidz1 on mixed size drives so i don't think it's a hard requirement like with hardware raid
mixing brands is usually better - all HDDs die, this is a fact. getting 10 drives at the same time from the same brand increases rhe chance that they were all made in the same run at the same time, and if one dies the others will soon follow.
having 10 drives from different brands decreases the chance that all your drives die at once, at least in theory
you also need to pay attention to drive speed - getting a 7.2k, 110MBps drive and mixing it with say a 5.4k 8MBps drive is just going to slow you down.

basically itcs just good practise to get drives from different brands, but that are all the same speed and size (and type, as in CMR vs SMR)

you could just get an m6 bolt and nut, put the bolt through the square hole, then through the rack and fasten the nut on the inside with a washer inbetween both the nut and the head of the bolt. the weight of the rail will be resting on the bolt either way, cage nut or not.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91057608
Sorry I don't get this post at all. That's the nicest way I can say you're almost completely wrong. You're criticizing speakers for being imperfect at replicating sound in a space, when headphones are even worse than speakers in this respect in the way people commonly get to use them. Especially people like OP asking questions that aren't audio enthusiasts.

Headphones can be the perfect device for simulating spatial sound, but the problem is you need custom HRTFs to do this. Getting HRTFs setup for yourself is one thing but your source must also be designed for HRTF to fully benefit, either recorded for HRTF or a game engine or whatever. But yes if you have HRTF, at worst you can simulate any number and location of speakers you like. I don't know the state of this is, last time I tried to acquire my own HRTF, it still wasn't easy. Most people are going to be using no HRTF, or some generic HRTF that spatializes sound only a little bit, and it works better or worse depending on how close your head and ear shape is to the reference.

Without HRTF, i.e. most of the time we talk about audio. Stereo speakers sound better than headphones for spatial qualities, both in the pleasing qualities of space and localization of sources. 4 speakers is also enough to envelop you in sound if you know where to place them. You should read this if you haven't already:

https://we.riseup.net/assets/443799/Sound+Reproduction+The+Acoustics+and+Psychoacoustics+of+Loudspeakers+and+Rooms+Floyd+Toole.pdf

Also some things are going to be limited by the recording. If you can't hear some spatial quality of sound because it's recorded in stereo, you won't hear it on headphones either.

Also, forgot to mention. Bass shelf (in both in-ears and over ears) is actually not an effect of the ear canal simulation, but a deliberate tuning choice. Flat sub bass on headphones is perceived as lacking by most people due to the lack of tactile feedback that the actual bass in a room tends to have, hence a mild shelf (+4dB) on over ears and a steep shelf (+10dB) on in ears.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91068085
>get 5 inch studio monitors
>room shaking, bass incredibly boomy
Pull them away from the walls and corners , and move your listening position away from the back wall. If you have them on a table then the table is rattling with the speaker making your bass worse.
>bass heard through walls, the whole building can hear the low thump of the bass
lol ok. You're either playing them stupid loud or your walls are just hollow plasterboard. If the walls are just thin then there's nothing you're going to be able to fix. You can't seal a room from sound leakage without adding suspended floors and sealed fake walls etc.
Parametric EQing certain resonant bass frequencies isn't going to do anything at all. You hear it loud at one frequency due to your listening position being in a node. You EQ that node out and you still have the rest of the bass frequencies which will travel and resonate. Each different room and position will have its own resonance frequencies so you either do a full cut for all bass under 60hz or you figure out how to keep those drivers from rattling around.

I'd start off with heavy stands sat on concrete slabs or similar. Speakers located at least 12" from back wall and 24" from side walls.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It'll be easier if you posted an image of your room.
I genuinely can't see 5" drivers causing so much of an issue. I have 3x pairs of speakers here in a similar size room as yours, 14ftx13ftx8ft, 1 with 10" drivers >>91060503 [mine], and 2x others with 5" (JBL LSR6325P) and 4" drivers (Fostex PN.04) and don't have an issue with the smaller speakers travelling outside or into different rooms and my walls a thin as hell.
Do you have some Windows EQ or bass boost enabled in your audio drivers etc?
>That's just to get rid of the resonating frequencies? I assume it won't help with the bass leaking through walls?
It'll stop any vibration from the speakers from rattling suspended floors etc. The idea is to keep the speaker enclosure as stable as possible so it doesn't vibrate, so all energy produced by the speaker driver is pushed forwards out of the cone and not via any wobbly box it's sat in. You do this by having it sat on heavy things which is can't shake.
As for buying even smaller speakers. It won't matter. 5" speakers can't really produce much bass energy anyway, limiting it to 3" will give off a similar frequency response.

Have you tried blocking any ports in the KRKs so it's a sealed box?

4chan, a site of mystery
A place where anonymity is key
Posters come and posters go

It also has a wifi module but it's full on spyware and it goes directly to the manufacturers' portal and forces you to upload your data and work from there, which I know you would agree, is not cool. I tried to look for bluetooth extenders but all I could find are repeaters and they work for audio mostly, they don't really repeat the original bluetooth signal of whatever gizmo its linked to.
Are there any real bluetooth long range repeaters out there?

#include <tertium/cpu.h>
#include <tertium/std.h>

static void *
copy(void *v, usize n, int c)
{
    uchar *s;
    s = v;
    for (; n; --n) *s++ = c;
    return v;
}

/* Try to avoid compiler optimization */
static void *(* volatile set)(void *, usize, int) = copy;

void *
c_mem_set(void *v, usize n, int c)
{
    return set(v, n, c);
}

#!/bin/bash
shopt -s nullglob
for g in `find /sys/kernel/iommu_groups/* -maxdepth 0 -type d | sort -V`; do
echo "IOMMU Group ${g##*/}:"
for d in $g/devices/*; do
echo -e "\t$(lspci -nns ${d##*/})"
done;
done;

>>91057064
The numpad is a godsend if you need to manually enter tons of numbers.
I had a job where you had to punch in several hundred lines of 9 digit numbers daily and it was much slower and tedious to use the top row instead of the numpad.
First thing I was taught was never use the top row numbers because it will take so much longer to get through all of the numbers.

About a month into the job the lady I was working with had to take time off for surgery and they had another person fill her spot temporarily, this guy only used the top row numbers and it was painful how much slower he went through his work.
I would have all of the numbers checked in about hour and a half while it took my helper nearly 4 hours.
I basically ended up having to do double the work amount because the guy absolutely refused to use the numpad.

So no OP people do need the numpad.

But still, open Ableton now and go back to making dinner. When you come back it will be easier to get into it.
Then just give yourself the task of doing the smallest thing possible, like working for a minute or making a simple riff or something, and then shutting it down.

I have this alesis dm7, it takes up maybe 1.2m^2 so not too big. the pads are all a single velocity, no zones for the ride (edge/bell) or snare like fancier kits, though it does detect snare rim separately. The hat pedal is also not quite continuous, only outputs closed/half-open/open afaict. The single crash cymbal does have a choke sensor if you grab it in the right part but it doesn't work in addictive drums by default; might be able to midi map it but haven't yet.
Even with those limitations it's still more flexible than the 6 pad thing. I think you'd need at least 10 zones or to cover basic kit sounds. If you are space constrained you could pick up finger drumming on a small pad like that apk mini or a launchpad or whatever. no drum sticks but can still be satisfying imo.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91009780
They work differently outside of adding and subtracting. Subtractive synthesis doesn't give you nearly as much control. In additive you add the frequencies you want individually. In subtraction, you're not controlling specific frequencies, you're just changing the ones that are below or above a certain threshold. If they were opposites, you'd be able to get exactly the same sounds from both.

Let me tell you a story that will show itself to be pertinent to the situation.

An old (15+ years ago) Skype account of mine got hacked into. I couldn't recover the account, because I couldn't answer the arcane questions about what I did fifteen years ago (credit card numbers, contacts, last purchase amount, etc). The clearly fraudulent activity included using Skype Credit to purchase a Chinese phone card from a Chinese location. Well, I contact Microsoft IT and they ask me if I have recovered my account. No, I tell them. Then they say there's literally nothing I can do. The IT person suggests that I get people I know to report the account for suspicious activity. I tell them that there's no need, I am telling them about it right now with receipts. They say, again, there's nothing they can do about it.

I had to block the daily spam emails telling me there isn't enough money in the account to buy more Chinese call minutes. Meaning, the account has not been shut down 3 months after and probably never will be.

Now, imagine this situation after an automated system has essentially SWAT'd you. A warrant will be issued, a team of cops will kick in your door, shoot your dog, take all of your computers (and guns, and cash - civil forfeiture bitch), you will be held in jail, potentially go to trial. You'll have to call in to work and tell them you've been arrested but can't tell them for what, but that you are DEFINITELY innocent. Same with your family. Maybe the local newspaper writes about the local pedo that got raided.

The best outcome of this scenario, best possible case, is that an obese police officer tells you, "You are free to go," and they give you back some of the personal possessions they took, and perhaps they still work. And Apple will never have to deal with any of this. >>91043614
\a is the BEL character, it makes your terminal emulator make noise. It's annoying as shit and everyone who uses it should be lynched. \033[ is how ansi escape sequences start, you can also use \e[. In this case they're both for color. 38;2;255;0;0 is literally just 255/0/0 in RGB. m closes the sequence. 0;38m is not actually a valid sequence but 30-37 are (for cterm colors 0-7) so he's presumably relying on the terminal emulator to take the opportunity to reset back to its default color. I dunno how many will actually work like that but Konsole does. You should note that only 8-color palettes are actually part of the spec, people get to 16 by assuming that "intense" text is the brighter half of the 16-color palette. 256 and truecolor are just completely fucking made up but they're widely supported enough that it's not normally a problem. You can read more on ye olde https://wikiless.org/wiki/ANSI_escape_code

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>

typedef struct node {
    char* data;
    struct node* next;
    struct node* prev;
} node;

node* create_node(char* data) {
    node* new_node = (node*) malloc(sizeof(node));
    new_node->data = (char*) malloc(sizeof(char) * (strlen(data) + 1));
    strcpy(new_node->data, data);
    new_node->next = NULL;
    new_node->prev = NULL;
    return new_node;
}

void insert_at_beginning(node** head, char* data) {
    node* new_node = create_node(data);
    if (*head == NULL) {
        *head = new_node;
        return;
    }
    (*head)->prev = new_node;
    new_node->next = *head;
    *head = new_node;
}

void insert_at_end(node* head, char* data) {
    node* new_node = create_node(data);
    node* current = head;
    while (current->next != NULL) {
        current = current->next;
    }
    current->next = new_node;
    new_node->prev = current;
}

void insert_at_index(node** head, char* data, int index) {
    if (*head == NULL) {
        *head = create_node(data);
        return;
    }
    if (index == 0) {
        insert_at_beginning(head, data);
        return;
    }
    node* current = *head;
    int i;
    for (i = 0; i < index - 1; i++) {
        if (current->next == NULL) {
            break;
        }
        current = current->next;
    }
    node* new_node = create_node(data);
    new_node->prev = current;
    new_node->next = current->next;
    if (current->next != NULL) {
        current->next->prev = new_node;
    }
    current->next = new_node;
}

}

void rotate(double complex* arr, unsigned int len, unsigned int k) {
    double complex* temp = (double complex*)malloc(k*sizeof(double complex));
    unsigned int i;
    for(i = 0; i < k; i++) temp[i] = arr[i];
    for(i = 0; i < len-k; i++) arr[i] = arr[i+k];
    for(i = 0; i < k; i++) arr[i+len-k] = temp[i];
    free(temp);
}

int main() {
    double complex arr[] = {1.0 + 2.0*I, 3.0 + 4.0*I, 2.0 + 3.0*I, 5.0 + 7.0*I, 6.0 + 8.0*I};
    unsigned int len = sizeof(arr)/sizeof(arr[0]);

    qsort(arr, len, sizeof(double complex), (compare_func)compare_complex);
    rotate(arr, len, 2);

    for(unsigned int i = 0; i < len; i++)
        printf("%lf + %lfi\n", creal(arr[i]), cimag(arr[i]));

    return 0;
}

#include <stdio.h>

typedef struct {
    int x, y;
} Point;

Point* create_point(int x, int y) {
    Point* p = (Point*)malloc(sizeof(Point));
    p->x = x;
    p->y = y;
    return p;
}

int compare_points(const void* a, const void* b) {
    Point* p1 = *(Point**)a;
    Point* p2 = *(Point**)b;
    if(p1->x != p2->x) return p1->x - p2->x;
    else return p1->y - p2->y;
}

void sort_points(Point** points, int len) {
    qsort(points, len, sizeof(Point*), compare_points);
}

extern signed long int read  (signed int,       void *, unsigned long int);
extern signed long int write (signed int, const void *, unsigned long int);

extern signed int open  (const char *, signed int);
extern signed int close (              signed int);

signed int main (argc, argv)
const signed int     argc;
const char       * * argv; {
    signed        int input  = - 1;
    signed        int output = - 1;
    signed   long int stop   = + 1;
             char     a      = '0';
             char     z      = '0';
    unsigned char     data   = (unsigned char) 0X00;

    if (argc != 3)
        return (0XA0);

    if ((input = open (* (argv + 1), 0)) == - 1)
        return (0XF2);

    if ((output = open (* (argv + 2), 1 | 64 | 512)) == - 1)
        return (0XF2);

    loop:

    data = (unsigned char) 0X00;

    read_upper_4_bits:

    if ((stop = read (input, & a, (unsigned long int) 1)) == - 1)
        return (0XF0);

    if (stop == (signed long int) 0)
        goto exit;

    if (a == ' ' || a == '	' || a == '
')
        goto read_upper_4_bits;

    if (a >= '0' && a <= '9')
        data = (unsigned char) ((unsigned int) (a - '0') << 4);
    else if (a >= 'A' && a <= 'F')
        data = (unsigned char) ((unsigned int) (a - 'A' + '
') << 4);
    else
        return (0XEE);

    read_lower_4_bits:

    if ((stop = read (input, & z, (unsigned long int) 1)) == - 1)
        return (0XF0);

    if (stop == (signed long int) 0)
        goto exit;

    if (z == ' ' || z == '	' || z == '
')
        goto read_lower_4_bits;

    if (z >= '0' && z <= '9')
        data |= (unsigned char) (z - '0');
    else if (z >= 'A' && z <= 'F')
        data |= (unsigned char) (z - 'A' + '
');
    else
        return (0XEE);

    (void) write (output, & data, (unsigned long int) 1);

    if (stop > (signed long int) 0)
        goto loop;

    exit:

    if (close (input) != 0)
        return (0XF3);

    if (close (output) != 0)
        return (0XF3);

    return (0X3C);
}

#include <stdio.h>

#define DIVISOR_3 3
#define DIVISOR_5 5
#define FIZZ "Fizz"
#define BUZZ "Buzz"

const char* FizzBuzz(int number) {
    if (number % (DIVISOR_3 * DIVISOR_5) == 0) {
        return FIZZ BUZZ;
    } else if (number % DIVISOR_3 == 0) {
        return FIZZ;
    } else if (number % DIVISOR_5 == 0) {
        return BUZZ;
    } else {
        return number;
    }
}

int main(int argc, char* argv[]) {
    if (argc != 2) {
        printf("Invalid arguments!
");
        return -1;
    }
    int upper_limit = atoi(argv[1]);
    if (upper_limit <= 0) {
        printf("Invalid upper limit!
");
        return -1;
    }
    for (int i = 1; i <= upper_limit; ++i) {
        printf("%s
", FizzBuzz(i));
    }
    return 0;
}

Here bro, what you need to do is build a real NAS and then just run Plex on it.

I’d honestly just get a PC case with a lot of drive bays (like the Fractal 2 XL) and just fill it up with new 8TB drives. If you want to go pro, use a server CPU and ECC ram, but you can probably get away with something like a Ryzen 5 or better consumer CPU. Install TrueNAS on an SSD in there.

Setup your storage in a Raid Z2. This means you can have 2 drives die and not be SOL on the data. Of course do external backups of data you care about, since the Raid being able to resilver isn’t a guarantee.

Then you can install Plex as a TrueNAS app and then copy the files from your old system to you new one.

posts.com:
>>91067495
Sure, so right now you're using a Windows desktop with a bunch of USB drives to store all your stuff? That's a bad idea for a few reasons, but most importantly I don't trust external drives with anything important.

First things first, a NAS is basically just a computer that has a purpose of just saving files from other computers in your house. All of your drives are connected to it, and you can access it from other computers in your house. You can also run other software on it (like Plex), since it's just a computer.

TrueNAS is another operating system vs Windows. It's been created to just be a really solid NAS operating system. You can also use UnRAID (another NAS operating system), but it costs money. I would do some research on which one you'd rather use.

Now, you can just buy a whole NAS as a package. Things like a Synology NAS or something. There are a lot of them, but you will be locked into their ecosystem, for better or worse. This may be the route you want to go down, unless you like tinkering with computers.

Since TrueNAS/Unraid are just operating systems, you need a computer to install them on. I would just build a new PC or if you have one with enough SATA ports (the connector hard drives use inside a case), you can use that. This PC build would be one that has a case and enough plugs to connect it all up. >>91067443 I would also install the operating system on another drive instead of one with all of your data. That's missing from the parts list.


What I said about ECC Ram, it's a special type of computer memory, and it's designed for servers or other things where the data being correct is important. It contains logic to find and correct errors in memory, and it's typically recommended to use it for a NAS. It's more expensive, and you'd need to use a server processor to use it, but it might be worthwhile.

Lastly, hard drives die eventually, so you can try and prevent being screwed over by using something called RAID Z2.

posts.name: Anonymous`
posts.com:
>>91067495
>>91067633

RAID Z2, overly simplified, allows 2 of your hard drives to die and you can still access your data, since enough data is on your other drives that your NAS can figure out the missing data on the drives that died.

You can replace the dead drives with a new one, and then "set up" the new drives so you can go back to being able to have 2 drives die. This process is called "resilvering"

Now, when you have a hard drive die, if you bought them all at the same time, it's possible that when you replace the drive with a new one, that another drive dies during the resilvering process. If that happens, you're kinda fucked.

Because of that, if the videos or data or whatever is important to you, I would definitely back it up to something else, like BackBlaze or something, just so you're not completely fucked over if that happens.

I hope this helps you fren.

my FV43U LED does great blacks. not as black as OLED but about 90-95% there where you don't notice most of the time- just a faint 1 or 2 points up in the black/grey scale when looking at black borders in movies etc

Bad points are it has some motion smearing when compared to OLED when you scroll text on a screen. Also black text on white can look a little weird due to the sub pixel layout.

Noctua actually recommends A12x25 PWM only for the Corsair Airflow.
>Greetings from Noctua!

>Thank you very much for contacting us.

>Our recommendation would be: Front: 3x NF-A12x25 PWM Top: 2x NF-A12x25 PWM Rear: 1x NF-A12x25 PWM

>For best results in all types of application, we recommend the NF-A12x25 fan. Unlike the award-winning NF-F12 and NF-S12A models, which are specialised solutions for specific applications, the NF-A12x25 has been conceived to be a true all-rounder with superior performance in most common configurations: Whereas the NF-F12 is optimised for maximum static pressure and the NF-S12A is optimised for maximum airflow, the pressure to airflow (P/Q) curve of the NF-A12x25 has been carefully fine-tuned in the mid-section that is critical for achieving the best results in all common applications.

>The above chart compares the P/Q curves of the three fan models and maps them on sample impedance curves of a typical PC case, heatsink and radiator in order to demonstrate how much air the fans can push through when working against the airflow resistance that these applications represent. As can be seen from the chart, the NF-F12 produces higher maximum static pressure (top left) and the NF-S12A produces higher maximum airflow (bottom right), but at the relevant operating points, namely the impedance curves of the three sample applications, the NF-A12x25 provides a better balance of static pressure and airflow than the other two fans. This is the cornerstone of the NF-A12x25’s superior real-world performance.

>Kind regards, Kadir Gürbüz Your Noctua Support-Team
>>91062295
I have it like that exact setup as well (but with Arctic fans) and it works fine. The problem with putting an exhaust there is it sucks out the front intake fresh air.

>32" 1440p
Coming from your current 27" 1440p monitor I'm telling you now you won't be happy with the lower pixel density of the same resolution diluted across a larger panel size (everything text, icons, images, video, etc. will look blurrier). What do you want your new primary monitor to be used for most (text/productivity, movies, games)? A larger resolution benefits crispness of the former while having a higher refresh on a smaller resolution makes driving games easier.

I'd recommend saving an extra 60$ of your monitor budget because once you get to between $300-350 there are extremely fast fast 27" high-refresh 1440p IPS panels like the Gigabyte M27Q-P available and around $500 you can get nice 4K high-refresh monitors like the M28U that will be far sharper and more drastic of an upgrade over your current main TN panel display.

>>91068992
The JEDEC frequency range has approximately doubled with each generation. There's no rule that says it has to though; it's just the industry responding to demand. The biggest customers are enterprise/server manufacturers who have historically always demanded more bandwidth. That demand has been satisfied by increasing the clock speeds. If they run into some limit in this they may change tack and increase the bus width instead.

Before you throw it away, there's a thing I used to do when i was a tech-guy-MacGyver for the military:
Get yourself a hair dryer, or a clothes iron and aluminium foil, or an air soldering iron and heat that motherfucker up.
Don't melt it, you just want to heat it up real hot and nice for a minute or so, make sure to move the whatever you're using to heat it up so the heat does not concentrate on a single point in the GPU.
Just try it, if it's dead anyways hitting it with heat won't break it. it's a last resort. 5 minutes is enough if it's not way too hot.

You will never be a real software developer. You have no formal education, you have no CS foundation, you have no passion. You are a delusional man twisted by unrealistic dreams into a crude mockery of the holy profession.

All the "support" you get is two-faced and half-hearted. Behind your back people mock you. Your recruiters are disgusted and ashamed of you, and your interviewers laugh at your pathetic lack of competence behind closed doors.

Real software developers are utterly repulsed by you. Thousands of hours of coding since the age of 11 have allowed us to sniff out frauds like you with incredible efficiency. Even boot-campers who get jobs are not respected by true programmers. Your superficial, rote knowledge of programming is a dead giveaway. And even if you manage to trick an employer into interviewing you, he'll turn tail and bolt the second he gets a whiff of your blatant ineptitude.

You will never be employed. You wrench out a fake smile every single morning and tell yourself you're going to get a job, but deep down you feel the truth creeping up like a weed, ready to crush you under the unbearable weight.

Eventually it'll be too much to bear - you'll give up on your dream of that six figure salary with office ping pong and free meals, you'll buy a rope, tie a noose, put it around your neck, and plunge into the cold abyss. Your parents will find you, heartbroken but relieved that they no longer have to live with your unbearable shame and disappointment. They'll bury you with a headstone marked with your name and job title - only your job title won't read 'Software developer'. Every passerby for the rest of eternity will know a man who didn't make it is buried there. Your body will decay and go back to dust, and all that will remain of your legacy is a skull that was unmistakably too small to hold a software developer's brain.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

They'll bury you with a headstone marked with your name and job title - only your job title won't read 'Software developer'. Every passerby for the rest of eternity will know a man who didn't make it is buried there. This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
for best possible quality to filesize ratio use two-pass. it's also important to keep threads at 1 as multi-threaded encoding can produce artifacts

#! /bin/sh
ffmpeg -i $1 -c:v libvpx-vp9 -pass 1 -qmin 0 -qmax 50 -crf 10 -b:v 1M -threads 1 -tile-columns 0 -speed 4 -g 128 -aq-mode 0 -an -sn -f webm /dev/null

ffmpeg -i $1 -c:v libvpx-vp9 -pass 2 -qmin 0 -qmax 50 -crf 10 -b:v 1M -c:a libopus -b:a 64K -vbr on -threads 1 -tile-columns 0 -speed 0 -auto-alt-ref 1 -lag-in-frames 25 -g 128 -aq-mode 0 -sn -f webm output.webm

Im pretty sure that's not entirely true. If you set a static bitrate, it can use that and come to the filesize everytime.

its only using quality settings like qp and crf that it cannot know exactly because the bitrate is entirely variable and based on a an idea of quality. But you can still set limits to them and you either get a file that's smaller (the bitrate you set was generous for the quality), a file size that's the same (you set the right bitrate to match the quality) or a filesize that is also the same but worse (the quality was set too high and required more bitrate than you set at all times so it becamse constant bitrate again).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91048249
calculate a bitrate and tell it to use that (highly recommend you use 2-pass in this case, single-pass fixed-bitrate is only suitable for fixed-bandwidth applications such as radio transmission)

for example say you have a 1:45 video and want it to be about 4MB, you want to divide the size by the length, to get the amount of data per unit of time you can use, for example,
(4*1024*8*1000)/(1*60+45)

will give you the bits-per-second you can use as a bitrate argument to ffmpeg, that's
4*1024 = size in KiB
*8 = size in Kib
*1000 = size in b
and
1*60 = minutes in seconds
+45 = plus the seconds

the difference between 1 and 2 pass is that with 1 pass, the bitrate will be the same the whole way through the video, as ffmpeg can't know where best to use the bits before it encodes the video, while for 2 pass, the first pass analyzes the video, giving ffmpeg the information it needs on the second pass to distribute the available bits more intelligently, that is, using more bits during complex scenes, and less bits in still scenes, increasing the quality overall

clip related, using that formula putting in 6 seconds and 200KiB target, the resulting clip is a little bigger as this does not include container overhead and it's also just not exact, so undershoot the size a bit if it must be under a certain size
ffmpeg -i INTENSIFIES.webm -map 0:v -c:v libvpx-vp9 -b "(0.2*1024*8*1000)/(0*60+6)" -pass 1 -y out.webm
ffmpeg -i INTENSIFIES.webm -map 0:v -c:v libvpx-vp9 -b "(0.2*1024*8*1000)/(0*60+6)" -pass 2 -y out.webm

posts.com:
>>91048691
ffmpeg guesses the output format based on the filename extension you use (for example it assumes "-f webm" if you use "somename.webm")
with NUL as the filename, it can't tell what format you want it to output in, so you need to specify it manually, "-f matroska" and "-f nut" should work for just about any streams

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91048691
-map 0:v -an

this is redundant, -an excludes audio streams, while my -map 0:v instead includes video streams from the first input (and it's explicit, meaning any other kinds of streams are implicitly excluded)
this is more reliable as it will also exclude things like subtitles which you also can't post here
you can be more specific with -map 0:v:0 (first video stream of first file), but this is only needed if the input has more than one video stream, which is so rare i usually don't bother adding it

@echo off
::Width of video
SET WIDTH=720
::Bitrate in Kbps
SET BITRATE="500k"

echo ###############################
echo CONVERTING to WEBM
echo WIDTH = %WIDTH%
echo BITRATE = %BITRATE%

::if 2nd args is empty, then default to no audio
if "%2"=="" (
    ffmpeg -y -loglevel quiet -stats -hide_banner -i "%1" -c:v libvpx-vp9 -an -auto-alt-ref 4 -arnr-maxframes 7 -arnr-strength 4 -aq-mode 0 -quality good -g 300 -lag-in-frames 25 -pix_fmt yuv420p10le -speed 4 -cpu-used 4 -row-mt 1 -threads 8 -tile-columns 1 -tile-rows 1 -b:v %BITRATE% -qmin 24 -vf scale=-1:%WIDTH% "v%~n1-noaudio.webm"
    goto :END
) else (
    ffmpeg -y -loglevel quiet -stats -hide_banner -i "%1" -c:v libvpx-vp9 -c:a libopus -b:a 64k -auto-alt-ref 4 -arnr-maxframes 7 -arnr-strength 4 -aq-mode 0 -quality good -g 300 -lag-in-frames 25 -pix_fmt yuv420p10le -speed 4 -cpu-used 4 -row-mt 1 -threads 8 -tile-columns 1 -tile-rows 1 -b:v %BITRATE% -b:a 64k -ac 1 -qmin 24 -vf scale=-1:%WIDTH% "v%~n1-audio.webm"
    goto :END
)

:END
echo FIN.

There we go, this should work (and be more easily expandable):

@ECHO off

REM Filenames
SET inputfile="%~1"
for %%a in (%inputfile%) do (
    set "file=%%~fa"
    set "filename=%%~na"
)

REM Width of video
SET WIDTH=720

REM Bitrate in Kbps
SET BITRATE="500k"

REM Set audio codec
REM Check for audio
IF "%2"=="" (
    SET "audioCodec=-an"
    SET "outFilename=v_%filename%_noaudio.webm"
) else (
    SET "audioCodec=-c:a libopus -b:a 64k -b:a 64k -ac 1"
    SET "outFilename=v_%filename%_audio.webm"
)

REM Set video codec
SET "videoCodec=-c:v libvpx-vp9 -auto-alt-ref 4 -arnr-maxframes 7 -arnr-strength 4 -aq-mode 0 -quality good -g 300 -lag-in-frames 25 -pix_fmt yuv420p10le -speed 4 -cpu-used 4 -row-mt 1 -threads 8 -tile-columns 1 -tile-rows 1 -b:v %BITRATE% -qmin 25 -vf scale=-1:%WIDTH%"

REM Set general options
SET "options=-y -loglevel quiet -stats -hide_banner"

REM Display
ECHO ###############################
ECHO CONVERTING %file%
ECHO to WEBM    %outFilename%
ECHO WIDTH   = %WIDTH%px
ECHO BITRATE = %BITRATE%
ECHO ###############################

ffmpeg %options% -i "%file%" %audioCodec% %videoCodec% "%outFilename%"

ECHO FIN.

@ECHO off

REM Filenames
SET inputfile="%~1"
for %%a in (%inputfile%) do (
    set "file=%%~fa"
    set "filename=%%~na"
)

REM Width of video
SET /a WIDTH=720

REM Bitrate in Kbps
SET /a BITRATE=900

REM Automatically reduces bitrate if the file size estimate is over 4MB
SET /a TARGET_SIZE=4
for /f "tokens=2 delims==" %%a in (
    'ffprobe "%file%" -show_entries format^=duration -v quiet -of compact'
) do (
    set duration=%%a
    set /a duration=duration
)
set /a CHECK_BITRATE=%BITRATE%*%duration%/8
IF NOT "%2"=="" ( set /a CHECK_BITRATE=%CHECK_BITRATE%-64 )
SET /a TARGET_SIZE=%TARGET_SIZE%*1000
if NOT %CHECK_BITRATE% LEQ %TARGET_SIZE% (
    set /a BITRATE=%TARGET_SIZE%*8/%duration%
)

REM Set audio codec
REM Check for audio
IF "%2"=="" (
    SET "audioCodec=-an"
    SET "outFilename=v_%filename%_noaudio.webm"
) else (
    SET "audioCodec=-c:a libopus -b:a 64k -ac 1"
    SET "outFilename=v_%filename%_audio.webm"
)

REM Set video codec
SET "videoCodec=-c:v libvpx-vp9 -auto-alt-ref 4 -arnr-maxframes 7 -arnr-strength 4 -aq-mode 0 -quality good -g 300 -lag-in-frames 25 -pix_fmt yuv420p10le -speed 4 -cpu-used 4 -row-mt 1 -threads 8 -tile-columns 1 -tile-rows 1 -b:v %BITRATE%k -qmin 25 -vf scale=-1:%WIDTH%"

REM Set general options
SET "options=-y -loglevel quiet -stats -hide_banner"

REM Display
ECHO ###############################
ECHO CONVERTING %file%
ECHO to WEBM    %outFilename%
ECHO WIDTH   = %WIDTH%px
ECHO BITRATE = %BITRATE%k
ECHO ###############################

ffmpeg %options% -i "%file%" %audioCodec% %videoCodec% "%outFilename%"

ECHO FIN.


Added a function to automatically adjust bitrate if the output estimate is higher than 4MB
