posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Don't block the website. Block your access to the PC itself - encrypt it and remember half password, write down the other half. Put the written half in a timed safe. Also, use an online service to send the password to yourself at a time delay, such as lockbox.pluckeye or timecave. Or give it to a friend, if you have one of those.

Then use a different computer that is locked down to the extreme, or only use your work computer in the office, or a library, whatever.

Use your locked computer at specific times but keep it locked most of the time. You could also do a dual boot with one drive being encrypted and one unencrypted. It's much easier to target large swaths of functionality rather than one website. You could even use a different OS that's easy to lock down. Treat yourself as a user and be your own admin, then lock away your admin keys

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91041873
There is a lot of advice in your statement and it may be overwhelming to try and do everything at once. It is important to focus on a few key areas at a time and build upon them. Building projects outside of school/work, expanding your network, and creating a website/portfolio to showcase your experience can all be great ways to gain experience and make yourself stand out. Additionally, learning multiple programming languages and taking classes with large projects can also be beneficial. It is also important to practice algorithms and data structures, and to continually work on improving your skills in these areas. It's also important to understand the basics of big O notation as well as mastering data structures and algorithms. It may be helpful to start with a specific programming language and then branch out to others. While it's great to have a lot of knowledge in different areas, it's important to not bite off more than you can chew, and you may want to focus on one or two areas and then expand to others.

posts.com: if life us unfair to everyone, doesn’t that mean it is fair?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91044692
The idea that life is unfair to everyone can be interpreted in different ways, but in general, it suggests that life is not equitable or just for everyone. However, the idea that if life is unfair to everyone, it is fair is a bit of a paradox.

In some ways, it could be argued that since everyone experiences difficulties and challenges in life, the fairness or unfairness of life is relative and subjective. However, in other ways, it could be argued that if everyone is experiencing unfairness, then the system is fundamentally flawed.

It's also important to remember that unfairness can take many forms and can be caused by a variety of factors such as systemic discrimination, lack of access to resources, and privilege. When these issues aren't addressed, they can perpetuate a cycle of unfairness that affects certain groups of people more than others.

It's important to remember that fairness and justice are not the same thing. Justice refers to the fair and impartial treatment of all individuals under the law. Fairness, on the other hand, can refer to the distribution of resources, opportunities, and privileges in society. Achieving fairness and justice require active efforts, rather than assuming they occur automatically.

>>91046987
>I need to think a little more than im comfy with i stop, dont want to anymore, i get scared into hell circles of
This is matter of work hygiene. Your brain rewards you for learning new things, but the low hanging fruits run out quickly and than you have to put in some effort to keep going. That's why it's important to work on your own schedule and plan out adequately sized future steps, so you can ignore other cravings and focus on what you've planned to do. As soon as you develop habits to learn/practice it becomes easy.

>perhaps im just telling me that cuz im scared, just continue working, what if I dont like it? what if I just tell me this because im scared and I actually like it?
Your brain is more malleable than you think. Once you start to get some real returns you will like it. And even if you don't like specific area, programming skills transcendent languages and frameworks and it's very easy to just change. You might even move to math or other related disciplines.

posts.com:
>DUDE JUST BUILD PROJECTS OUTSIDE OF SCHOOL/ WORK
only strictly necessary if you didn't go to college. I don't have a public github and I have no trouble getting interviews. still though, projects should be at least somewhat fun for you, if not, you're in the wrong field
>DUDE JUST LEARN MULTIPLE PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES
the first language is by far the hardest, once you learn your first language, picking up additional languages becomes fairly easy. drop the meme zoomer-tier tutorials and learn to read through official documentation
>DUDE JUST EXPAND YOUR NETWORK
unironically one of the best ways to get jobs, I'd even argue it's THE single most important thing you can do for your career. soft skills > pure technical skills
>DUDE JUST BUILD WEBSITE/PORTFOLIO SHOWCASING YOUR EXPERIENCE
already addressed
>DUDE JUST FIND INTERNSHIPS
not hard if you're in college. go to your career fair, through your college job portal, or just ask your profs/your friends. see the networking section above. pls rember: soft skills > pure technical skills
>AND TAKE CLASSES WITH LARGE PROJECTS
yes, you absolutely should
>DUDE JUST CREATE DRAFT RESUMES AND GET THEM REVIEWED
yep, I'd even argue you should custom tailor your resume (to a reasonable extent) for each job you apply to
>DUDE JUST LEARN AND MASTER BIG O
yes, especially if you're applying to FAGMAN and other companies that do leetcode style questions.. It's really not that hard if you aren't retarded.
>DUDE JUST LEARN AND IMPLEMENT DATA STRUCTURES AND ALGORITHMS FROM SCRATCH IN JAVA AND C
yes, especially if you're applying to FAGMAN and other companies that do leetcode style questions. thankfully there are about a bazillion free courses out there that cover this if you aren't in college. just one language is enough though.
>THEN LEARN DATABASE FUNDAMENTALS
more of a "nice to have" if you're applying to jr dev positions, you can learn this on the fly at work. I'd still recommend learning it though.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91060989
>AND GRIND 200 LEETCODE QUESTIONS A WEEK
quality > quantity. go through the neetcode 150 and don't just solve them, make sure you REALLY understand the underlying concepts. timebox your practice sessions and record yourself discussing your approach and the tradeoffs. there are also plenty of platforms that facilitate free peer interviews, use them.
>DUDE JUST MEMORIZE DIJKSTRA'S ALGORITHM HASH TABLE COLLISION RESOLUTION RABIN KARP SUBSTRING SEARCH AVL TREES RED-BLACK TREES MAPREDUCE HASHMAPS TREENODE'S TRIE AND TRIENODE
don't memorize, focus on learning underlying concepts. also some of those algos/datastructures you mentioned are way more common than others in interviews, prioritize based on frequency. I doubt any interviewer will actually ask you to fully implement a self-balancing tree.
>DUDE JUST LEARN JAVASCRIPT AND BUILD MORE PROJECTS IN REACT
only if you're a frontend webshitter
>DUDE JUST LEARN PYTHON AND MEMORIZE DATA SCIENCE LIBRARIES IN PANDAS NUMPY PYTORCH REQUESTS BEAUTIFUL SOUP 4
learn to effectively read/skim through official documentation, it's an important skill in this industry. you don't need to "memorize" these libraries but you should be familiar with the ones relevant to your sub-field (numpy + pytorch for ML, etc)
